<str>Doom is a special resource that the GM gains at the start of each combat encounter based on the Challenge Rating (CR) of the encounter, as detailed in the Doom by Encounter Tier table.</str>

<str>The GM can spend Doom to give a creature advantage on an attack roll, give a PC disadvantage on a save, or once per encounter, refresh, recharge, or otherwise gain one additional use of a limited-use feature, such as a dragon's Breath Weapon, a legendary creature's Legendary Resistance, or a spell in a mage's Spellcasting.</str>
<str>Doom exists to give creatures some extra staying power against particularly powerful, crafty, or resourceful PCs.</str>

<str>The GM should consider using Doom in an encounter if it is likely the only combat encounter the PCs will face that day and the PCs are well-rested, if there are multiple experienced players, if there are more than four players, if the players' characters have extra magic items, resources, optimized statistics, or similar aspects that make them tougher than average PCs, or if the encounter is particularly significant to the story.</str>

<str>What is a stat block, and how is it organized?</str>

<str>A stat block is an easy-reference format that organizes the information needed to use a creature in the game. It includes headings for Description and Lore, Abilities, Armor Class, Hit Points, Speed, Saving Throws, Skills, Senses, Languages, Challenge Rating, Traits, Actions, Reactions, and Legendary Actions.</str>
<str>What is the purpose of the Description and Lore heading in a stat block?</str>
<str>The Description and Lore heading provides an italicized description of the creature, as well as lore describing its origins, typical motives, and similar.</str>
<str>What information is included in the Abilities heading of a stat block?</str>
<str>The Abilities heading includes the creature's ability scores, which are Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma.</str>
<str>What is the Armor Class (AC) of a creature, and how is it calculated?</str>
<str>Armor Class (AC) represents how difficult it is to hit a creature with an attack. It is calculated by adding the creature's Dexterity modifier and any bonuses from armor or other sources.</str>
<str>What is the purpose of the Hit Points (HP) heading in a stat block?</str>
<str>The Hit Points (HP) heading indicates how much damage a creature can take before it is defeated.</str>
<str>What is the Speed of a creature, and how is it determined?</str>

<str>Speed represents how far a creature can move in a round. It is determined by the creature's base speed, which is modified by any bonuses or penalties from abilities, spells, or other sources.</str>
<str>What are Saving Throws, and how are they used?</str>

<str>Saving Throws represent a creature's ability to resist certain effects, such as spells or abilities. They are made by rolling a d20 and adding the creature's ability modifier and any bonuses or penalties from abilities, spells, or other sources.</str>
<str>What are Skills, and how are they used?</str>

<str>Skills represent a creature's proficiency in certain tasks. They are made by rolling a d20 and adding the creature's ability modifier and any bonuses or penalties from abilities, spells, or other sources.</str>
<str>What are Senses, and how do they work?</str>
<str>Senses represent a creature's ability to perceive its surroundings. They include sight, hearing, smell, taste, and touch.</str>
<str>What are Languages, and how are they used?</str>
<str>Languages represent a creature's ability to communicate with other creatures. They are listed in the Languages heading of a stat block.</str>
<str>What is the Challenge Rating (CR) of a creature, and how is it determined?</str>
<str>Challenge Rating (CR) represents the difficulty of a creature in combat. It is determined by the creature's abilities, hit points, and other factors.</str>
<str>What are Traits, Actions, Reactions, and Legendary Actions, and how are they used?</str>

<str>Traits are special abilities that a creature possesses. Actions are things that a creature can do on its turn. Reactions are things that a creature can do outside of its turn. Legendary Actions are special abilities that legendary creatures can use.</str>
<str>What is the purpose of categories in creature types?</str>
<str>Categories denote that creatures are more closely related to each other than they are to other creatures of the same creature type.</str>
<str>Do categories have any game rules associated with them?</str>
<str>No, categories do not have any game rules that reference or rely on them.</str>
<str>Categories can be helpful when determining which creatures might be found together or working alongside each other.</str>
<str>What is an example of a category?</str>
<str>Goblin, Creature Name is a category that includes bugbears, goblins, and hobgoblins.</str>
